2302.name: Tit Bits
2302.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 24 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
2302.notes_html:
Description from Knitty.com:

I went to every mastectomy boutique and medical supply store in the city. There were titties of every shape, size and skin color (from beige to dark brown) but none were what I wanted -- perky, cute and comfortable. They were too heavy, squishy or ugly.


…

To cheer myself up, I rummaged through my stash looking for something luxurious to knit up. Then it hit me that I could knit myself a new titty; in fact, I had so much yarn I could knit myself a different titty for every day of the week, month, year!


I finished my first knitted titty an hour before the party and wore it with one of my favorite lacy underwires. When a friend, who had been following the whole titty saga, saw me she remarked, "You really did a great job! Your left breast looks almost as good as the right one -- a bit lumpy but very realistic."


"You know," I replied, "It was my right breast that was removed."

NOTE: Tit bits has recently been featured in the new book KnitKnit.

Also on Debbie Macombers site.

To cheer myself up, I rummaged through my stash looking for something luxurious to knit up. Then it hit me that I could knit myself a new titty; in fact, I had so much yarn I could knit myself a different titty for every day of the week, month, year!

users.about_me:
Fiber Trends was established in 1994 by Bev Galeskas with the printing of one pattern followed by five more the next month. From the beginning, Fiber Trends patterns were sold through retail yarn stores, this continued support has allowed us to expand our line to over 200 patterns. 

Fiber Trends now resides in East Wenatchee, which is pretty much smack in the middle of the state of Washington. We are continually working on new knitting and crochet designs to offer along with our leather and knitting felting products.

If you have a question about a Fiber Trends pattern please email debbie@fibertrends.com rather than leaving a message here. Thank you!

Like us on Facebook to see new products!  


  [1]: http://www.fibertrends.com

20516.name: Reusable tampon
20516.notes_html:
From the pattern notes:

“I used some Rowan 4 ply cotton I had on hand, but a much better yarn would be be an unbleached 4 ply Hemp. Some sources I know of are http://www.houseofhemp.co.uk/acatalog/Natural.html which is 100% hemp yarn and http://www.lanaknits.com/usahempton.html which is a 50% cotton 50% hemp mix. House of Hemp are based in the UK and Lanaknits are based in Canada but both sell worldwide.

Using hemp would make the tampons ultimately compostable and the hemp plant is very good for the ground it’s grown in. The yarn when you buy it is often crisp and coarse feeling, but once washed it becomes much softer and more comfortable on the skin, which is fairly important for this pattern

If you’d prefer cotton or are having difficulty finding hemp, them please use an unbleached 4 ply cotton yarn.“

Using hemp would make the tampons ultimately compostable and the hemp plant is very good for the ground it's grown in. The yarn when you buy it is often crisp and coarse feeling, but once washed it becomes much softer and more comfortable on the skin, which is fairly important for this pattern 

If you'd prefer cotton or are having difficulty finding hemp, them please use an unbleached 4 ply cotton yarn."

users.about_me:
I have lived in Burien all my life.  We are about 15 minutes south of downtown Seattle.  1 1/2 years ago, I left my job at Trader Joe's to go into business with my daughter.

Can you guess what we decided to do?  That would be it.  We bought an  existing yarn shop, moved it to the main street of Burien and have been having so much fun, that this can't possibly be called work.

38588.name: Bandages for Leprosy Patients
38588.notes_html:
The Bandage Brigade program is over (“Mission accomplished!” they say http://dovefund.org/bandage_brigade.htm) and no longer accepting new bandages.

From Pattern Notes

Size: approximately 3 inches wide by 4 feet long.
Material specifications: No. 10 knit Cro-sheen, 100% mercerized cotton in white, cream or ecru. It’s bedspread cotton. (1 ‘ball/skein’ will make 2 - 4 ft long bandages.)

Please no dyes. South Maid D54 is the suggested brand, although other brand names like JP Coats, knit Cro Sheen etc, are welcome if they meet these specifications.

When completed, please wash the bandages, roll them and secure with a large safety pin. Put in plastic bag, remove air, and seal.
38588.notes:
The Bandage Brigade program is over (“Mission accomplished!” they say http://dovefund.org/bandage_brigade.htm) and no longer accepting new bandages.

Please no dyes. South Maid D54 is the suggested brand, although other brand names like JP Coats, knit Cro Sheen etc, are welcome if they meet these specifications.

When completed, please wash the bandages, roll them and secure with a large safety pin. Put in plastic bag, remove air, and seal.

65235.name: Face Punch Relaxation Mask
65235.notes_html:
If you want to buy some luxury yarn but are afraid you might slip into a coma at the thought of a sweaters worth, try knitting this super easy eye or relaxation mask instead.

The cables are also pretty easy to do, so it would make a great project for a first try at cables.

pattern_author.name: Terry Neal
pattern_author.notes:
A team of two, Caneda and I design and write the patterns for Elusive Designs.  After 14 years growing Tempe Yarn & Fiber, we have come to understand what knitters are looking for in a pattern.  

It starts with an idea, then we bounce the concepts around, while   Caneda decides what is and isn't able to translate to written work so it makes sense. ( I get a little crazy sometimes with the designs.)  

While I have more ideas than I know what to do with from all the swatches and miniatures I create, Caneda is the one who helps organize and document  what I do, coordinates the testing of the patterns, then rewrites all that technical stuff, so you get a pretty solid pattern.

 We love that we can offer our patterns here on  Ravelry for those who can't personally visit Tempe Yarn & Fiber.

Happy Knitting,
Terry

*Please note...patterns with no photos are no longer available and have been discontinued.

We love that we can offer our patterns here on Ravelry for those who can’t personally visit Tempe Yarn & Fiber.

users.about_me:
Fiber & Yarn....can't imagine life without them!

Next to learning a new technique, my favorite part of the fiber world is teaching. I’ve taught at the local level, and at At Arizona’s Federation of Weavers and Spinners Retreat Events, Black Sheep Gathering, and several fiber retreats. 
 
My niece Caneda and I design and write patterns under the name “Elusive Designs”.  I have more ideas than I know what to do with, but luckily Caneda is able to translate my concepts into organized patterns!
 
Seventeen years ago, my husband and I opened our own shop, Tempe Yarn & Fiber, where I can be surrounded by beautiful yarn, including my exclusive line, Dyelicious.  I teach as often as I can, and I am reaching out beyond the shop now, to teach fellow travelers some new fiber tricks on upcoming retreats.  Sign up for our newsletter to find out what’s new in the store.  Keep an eye out for my next adventures which will include some travel!
 

Tempe Yarn Link: [Tempe Yarn][1]



  [1]: https://Http://www.tempeyarn.com

414495.name: Knitted Knockers in the Round
414495.gauge_description: 5 stitches and 7 rows = 1 inch in stockinette
414495.notes_html:
I wrote this up because the head lactation consultant where I went for breastfeeding support while nursing my son asked for knitted breasts for teaching aids.

This is a modified version of “Knitted Breast” by Carolyn Westcott. My version is knit in the round, modular and uses thicker yarn and therefore a different number of stitches.

You can also forgo the base and make it into a baby hat.

Unfortunately, I can't offer my soaker pattern as a Raverly download because it is a spreadsheet.  You can find it in my etsy shop instead. Find news about upcoming patterns or help with existing patterns in the [Neon Unicorn Studios Ravelry Group.][2]

578140.name: Well Tempered Baseball
578140.notes_html:
Here’s a toy, which is also home remedy, because it can be used as a hot-and-cold pack! My samples are about 3x3x3 inches (7x7x7 cm) in worsted weight yarn. You can use thinner yarn double-threaded. But, please, make sure it’s microwaveable and washable, if you want to use it as a hot-pack. You will need approximately 50 yards altogether white yarn, 2 yards of red scrap yarn and 1-2 cups of dry corn, beans or lentils. I recommend to fill the toy with dry beans, because are very pliable, but large enough not to escape too easily. The pattern gives tips for easy reopening. A cotton liner bag for the filling is optional. Seaming is obligatory - it’s a baseball after all :)

It’s knit flat. Otherwise the making of this toy requires knitting skills like knit, purl, increase, decrease, and definitely seaming.

Please check out my other “well tempered patterns” - proceeds are going towards yarn and other supplies, like beans for example. My charity knitting group “craft around corners” makes toys and other hand-knit items, which are donated to various good causes. With the proceeds of only one of the patterns we can make about ten toys!

users.about_me:
Both my grandmothers taught me how to crochet and how to knit when I was just a little kid. They kindled my interest by showing me new patterns and challenging me to start new projects until I was completely and utterly hooked.

When I went to the US in 2012, I found myself in the lucky position to have the head space and time to learn again and follow my dreams, pursue my hobbies and indulge my passions - like knitting for example.

Now, I’m back in Germany. But knitting never stops.

638630.name: Knockers (Crochet)
638630.notes_html:
Yarn for crocheted knockers is very important as it will be worn against sensitive, scarred skin. We recommend soft, washable, nonwool sport, baby or “3” weight yarn. Worsted is too heavy. If cotton it should be mercerized to stay soft after washing.

We get the most request for pairs of neutral colors sizes C and larger at knittedknockers.org.

We get the most request for pairs of neutral colors sizes C and larger at knittedknockers.org.

1176417.name: Knitted Knockers on DPNs
1176417.sizes_available: A, B, C, D, E cups
1176417.notes_html:
Stay in the loop on free pattern promos and more!

Follow us on Instagram | Sign up for our Newsletter

What are Knitted Knockers?

Knitted Knockers are special handmade breast prostheses for women who have undergone mastectomies or other procedures to the breast. Traditional breast prostheses are usually expensive, heavy, sweaty, and uncomfortable. They typically require special bras or camisoles with pockets, and they can’t be worn for many weeks after surgery. Knitted Knockers, however, are soft, comfortable, beautiful, and when placed in a regular bra - they take the shape and feel of a real breast. Knitted Knockers can be adjusted to fill a gap for uneven breasts, and they are easily adapted for those going through reconstruction by simply removing some of the stuffing.

Materials
1 set 6” double point needles, size US 5 or 6. HiKoo® Cobasi DK (55% Cotton, 16% Bamboo, 8% Silk, 21% Elastic Nylon - 140 yards per 50-gram skein), tapestry needle.

Knitted Knockers, however, are soft, comfortable, beautiful, and when placed in a regular bra - they take the shape and feel of a real breast. Knitted Knockers can be adjusted to fill a gap for uneven breasts, and they are easily adapted for those going through reconstruction by simply removing some of the stuffing.

**Materials**

7335892.name: Retention Bandage (Crocheted)
7335892.notes_html:
THIS IS THE CROCHET PATTERN.

These cotton retention bandages may be used for medical conditions with chronic skin ulcers which need regular wound care. It can be washed and reused. It is an alternative to disposable store-bought bandages.

Please secure your doctor’s/health provider’s approval before using these bandages.

BACKGROUND

On April 4, 2024 I posted a request on Facebook and Instagram for help with this project. In truth, I had expected only a few to come forward. I never expected thousands of knitters and crocheters to offer their help.

I am very grateful for many, many kind individuals.

These cotton retention bandages are reusable bandages that are placed over the primary wound dressing. These are for our patients with Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) who have chronic, non-healing wounds. They are patients at the University of the Philippines-Philippine General Hospital (UP-PGH) Department of Dermatology.

OVERVIEW
Please be guided by the following:
-please use only 100% cotton or mercerized cotton, lace weight (CYC #0), 26-27 wraps per inch (WPI). These are bandages for medical use and must be thin.
-please DO NOT use any synthetic fiber (no acrylic, cotton blends, polyester, raylon, milk cotton, poly cotton, lanalon, indophil)
-undyed, bare, white, cream, natural, and off-white only (no color dyes which can potentially irritate open wounds )

THREAD
-for those who live in the Philippines – Monaco mercerized cotton 3-ply balls or cone, Cannon mercerized cotton 3-ply ball or cone, Monaco CCK83 mercerized cotton 3-ply cone
-for those who live in other countries – cotton crochet thread size 10. A list of suggested thread/yarn is included in the pattern. It will be updated as often as necessary. The updated list will also be posted in the Knits by May Facebook group under the Guides tab - Retention Bandages https://www.facebook.com/groups/knitsbymay/

-the gauge is not important. Please adjust the size of your knitting needles or crochet hook depending on your personal gauge/tension to produce the right fabric.

I have set up chat groups within a Facebook group for updates and to answer your questions. Joining the Knits by May Facebook group and the chat group is purely voluntary. The link to the group is https://www.facebook.com/groups/knitsbymay/ then join the chat for your location.

As of April 2024, there are two chats (PH and Worldwide). In the Worldwide chat there are side chats for US/Canada and Australia/New Zealand.

Many, many thanks to Ariett07 for converting the hand-knitting pattern into a machine-knitting pattern.

Thank you all for your generosity and willingness to share your time and your talent.

Dr. May

——-

June 2024 update

  • includes option for 4-inch wide bandages
  • additional thread options
7335892.notes:
THIS IS THE CROCHET PATTERN.

These cotton retention bandages may be used for medical conditions with chronic skin ulcers which need regular wound care. It can be washed and reused. It is an alternative to disposable store-bought bandages.

Please secure your doctor’s/health provider’s approval before using these bandages.

------ 

BACKGROUND

On April 4, 2024 I posted a request on Facebook and Instagram for help with this project. In truth, I had expected only a few to come forward. I never expected thousands of knitters and crocheters to offer their help. 

I am very grateful for many, many kind individuals.

These cotton retention bandages are reusable bandages that are placed over the primary wound dressing. These are for our patients with Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) who have chronic, non-healing wounds. They are patients at the University of the Philippines-Philippine General Hospital (UP-PGH) Department of Dermatology.


OVERVIEW
Please be guided by the following:
-please use only 100% cotton or mercerized cotton, lace weight (CYC #0), 26-27 wraps per inch (WPI). These are bandages for medical use and must be thin.
-please DO NOT use any synthetic fiber (no acrylic, cotton blends, polyester, raylon, milk cotton, poly cotton, lanalon, indophil)
-undyed, bare, white, cream, natural, and off-white only (no color dyes which can potentially irritate open wounds )

THREAD
-for those who live in the Philippines – Monaco mercerized cotton 3-ply balls or cone, Cannon mercerized cotton 3-ply ball or cone, Monaco CCK83 mercerized cotton 3-ply cone 
-for those who live in other countries – cotton crochet thread size 10. A list of suggested thread/yarn is included in the pattern. It will be updated as often as necessary. The updated list will also be posted in the Knits by May Facebook group under the Guides tab - Retention Bandages https://www.facebook.com/groups/knitsbymay/ 

-the gauge is not important. Please adjust the size of your knitting needles or crochet hook depending on your personal gauge/tension to produce the right fabric.


I have set up chat groups within a Facebook group for updates and to answer your questions. Joining the Knits by May Facebook group and the chat group is purely voluntary. The link to the group is https://www.facebook.com/groups/knitsbymay/ then join the chat for your location. 

As of April 2024, there are two chats (PH and Worldwide). In the Worldwide chat there are side chats for US/Canada and Australia/New Zealand. 

Many, many thanks to Ariett07 for converting the hand-knitting pattern into a machine-knitting pattern.

Thank you all for your generosity and willingness to share your time and your talent.


Dr. May 

——- 

June 2024 update
- includes option for 4-inch wide bandages
- additional thread options

7347039.gauge_pattern: stitch pattern (gauge swatch instructions given in pattern)
7347039.name: Little Love Cannula Sleeve
7347039.gauge_description: 19 stitches and 17 rows = 4 inches in stitch pattern (gauge swatch instructions given in pattern)
7347039.notes_html:
This pattern was designed for the Preemie Crochet Challenge 2024.

Bust your stash while helping babies and families in need! This sweet little cannula sleeve works up quickly in a lighter worsted or DK yarn and is a fun and easy way to bring some comfort to babies and parents during a trying time.

Cannula sleeves are used to prevent preemie babies from scratching themselves on the tubes they are hooked up to, and they can also ease the mind of a parent who is distressed at the sight of all those tubes on their little one. Join us in crafting for a cause and use your yarn leftovers to make a few to donate!

Level: Advanced beginner (sc, dc, front/back loop)

Construction: Worked flat and in one piece, with a crocheted border and slip stitch join.

Yarn: A lighter worsted (4) or heavier DK (3) yarn would work. My sample used WeCrochet Comfy Worsted in Peony.

Want to see some free versions of my pattern writing first? Check out the links here!

I’d love to see your makes! Create a Ravelry project linked to the pattern and/or post on Instagram with the hashtags #PreemieCrochetChallenge, #LittleLoveCannulaSleeve and #ClairdeLuneFiberArt (tag me @clairdelunefiberart)!

Due to the nature of PDF patterns, I cannot offer any refunds on them. If you have any issues with this pattern, please email me at clairdelunefiberart@gmail.com and I’ll do whatever I can to help!

pattern_author.name: Allison Bostrom
pattern_author.notes:
I design stimulating crochet and knit patterns for everything from garments and accessories to homewares. My goal in writing patterns is to encourage makers to learn new stitches and construction techniques, or to reconsider the ones they know. Though working with yarn is always relaxing for me, I find a real joy in pushing myself to do something new and different with yarn. Wherever possible, I include photo tutorials for both lefties and righties to make my patterns more approachable.

Besides fiber arts, I love cooking, baking, gardening, reading, doing puzzles, and playing piano and guitar.

**If you’d like to be notified about sales, pattern releases, and tester calls, feel free to sign up for my email list: http://eepurl.com/gthR_D.**

[Instagram][1] | [Facebook][2]

**Interested in some free samples of my pattern writing?**
**Free Crochet Patterns:**
[Mermaid Scales Cowl and Headband Set][3]
[Picnic in the Park Jar Cozies][4]
[Crocus Cocoon Shrug][5]
[Tide Pool Tank][6]

**Free Knitting Patterns:**
[Sprinkles on Top Cowl][7]
[Umbral Shawl][8]
[Swallowtail Square][9]


  [1]: https://www.Instagram.com/clairdelunefiberart
  [2]: https://www.Facebook.com/clairdelunefiberart
  [3]: https://joyofmotioncrochet.com/mermaid-scales-cowl-and-headband-set-free-crochet-pattern/
  [4]: https://joyofmotioncrochet.com/picnic-in-the-park-jar-cozies/
  [5]: https://desamourdesigns.com/2021/03/25/crocus-cocoon-shrug-by-clair-de-lune-fiber-art/
  [6]: https://www.twobrothersblankets.com/crochet-tide-pool-tank/
  [7]: https://nohooksgiven.com/2020/09/20/designer-spotlight-clair-de-lune-fiber-art/
  [8]: https://knittingwithchopsticks.com/umbral-shawl-knitting-pattern/
  [9]: https://knittingwithchopsticks.com/swallowtail-blanket-square-knitting-pattern/

7361447.name: Wirbelkreise
7361447.notes_html:
Diese Wirbelkreise sind nützlich zum Abbau von Stress. Aber auch hilfreich für an Demenz erkrankte Personen, da die Hände eine gute Beschäftigung finden. Und machen auch einfach so Spaß.

Da man diese Wirbelkreise oder auch korallenähnlichen Teile aus so ziemlich jedem Garn häkeln kann, gibt es keine genaue Garnangabe oder Maschenprobe.

Empfehlenswert ist das Verwenden von Baumwolle, gegebenenfalls mit Ökotex Zertifizierung, wegen der besseren Waschbarkeit. Man kann sehr gut Reste verwenden.

Die Anleitung steht als ausgeschriebene Anleitung und auch als Videoanleitung zur Verfügung.

7388226.name: Blue Bunny Hot/Cold Water Bottle Cover
7388226.sizes_available: with cuff folded- 14.5" (37 cm) tall by 15" (38 cm) circumference
7388226.gauge_description: 34 stitches and 39 rows = 4 inches in stranded st st colorwork, blocked
7388226.notes_html:
There’s nothing like a nice hot or cold water bottle to soothe an achy body. Even better if it has a soft, cute cover! This cover was designed with a beautiful hand-dyed Merino wool yarn and a handspun Merino/Angora yarn that will produce a nice, soft halo with use. The cover will fit a standard 2 liter classic rubber hot water bottle with a flat bottom commonly found in the US.

SIZE: with cuff folded- 14.5” tall by 15” circumference/37 cm tall by 38 cm circumference to fit a 2 liter rubber water bottle

GAUGE:
34 sts & 39 rows = 4“ 10 cm in stranded st st pattern after blocking

MATERIALS:
2 contrasting colors of fingering weight yarn:
Shown above in MC: Zippy Zebra Hand Dyed Merino Sock Yarn, 100 g (3.5 oz)/ 429 yds (392 m); colorway: sapphire; 1 skein and CC: handspun 2-ply Merino-Angora blend yarn 28g (1oz)/ 136 yds (125 m); colorway: Pancake/fawn; 1 skein (available in my Etsy shop)
16”/40 cm long U.S. 2 (2.75 mm) circular knitting needles (or size needed to obtain gauge)- 2 sets or one set and a set of double pointed needles in same size for cuff
3 stitch markers, 1 unique
Darning needle

Special thanks to my proof-reader, Konane!

Eligible for entry in this 2025 KAL

Please join us in Settlers Grove Designs for KALs and project sharing!

users.about_me:
My name is Stefanie Johnson. My mom introduced me to textile crafting at an early age with cross stitch, latch hook and sewing projects, sparking a love for textiles and fiber arts that has grown exponentially! I began knitting in 1999 after stumbling across a pattern for a knit sweater, and I learned to spin in 2008 following decades of fascination with spinning wheels. 

I have had work published in Spin Off Magazine and their blog, as well as Taproot Magazine, Knitty, and Knotions. I especially love to create unique items for the children in my life, and to help others learn to spin, knit and weave. At Settlers Grove, our hobby farm established in 2012, we raise French Angora rabbits, bees, and a variety of chickens and ducks. I sell some of the angora fiber in my [Etsy shop][1]

Please join us over in [Settlers Grove Designs](/groups/settlers-grove-designs) for KALs and project sharing!

Happy knitting!

*My new self-published patterns are always 20% off during the first week!*


  [1]: https://settlersgrove.etsy.com/
